dt.t: Bartlett allows his preliminary wash or {d_link|grisaille|grisaille} to dry and then applies transparent layers of broken color. Into this wash he adds the {wi}lights{/wi} and darks as they have been mapped out underneath.
always washed his {wi}lights{/wi} separately from his darks
the {wi}light{/wi} shines in the darkness, and the darkness has not overcome it
reaching out and groping for a pathway to the {wi}light{/wi}

dt: {bc}a particular aspect or appearance presented to view

dt.t: saw the matter in a different {wi}light{/wi}

{bc}a set of principles, standards, or opinions
{bc}a noteworthy person in a particular place or field

dt: {bc}a flame for lighting something (such as a cigarette)

et: Middle English {it}liht, light,{/it} going back to Old English {it}lēoht,{/it} Anglian {it}lēht,{/it} going back to Germanic {it}*leuh-t-,{/it} neuter noun (whence also Old Frisian {it}liācht{/it} "light," Old Saxon {it}lioht,{/it} Middle Dutch {it}licht, lich,{/it} Old High German {it}lioht{/it}), probably syncopated from an earlier consonantal stem {it}*leuhađa-,{/it} as in Gothic {it}liuhaþ{/it} "light," derivative of an Indo-European base {it}*leu̯k-{/it} "become bright," whence Sanskrit {it}rócate{/it} "(it) shines, is bright," Avestan {it}raociṇt-{/it} "brightening," Hittite {it}lukta{/it} "it becomes light, dawns"
Gothic {it}liuhaþ{/it} has been compared directly with Hittite {it}lukkatt-{/it} "dawn, next morning."
shortdef: something that makes vision possible
the sensation aroused by stimulation of the visual receptors

electromagnetic radiation of any wavelength that travels in a vacuum with a speed of 299,792,458 meters (about 186,000 miles) per second; specifically : such radiation that is visible to the human eye

dt: {bc}not intense in color, coloring, or {d_link|pigmentation|pigmentation} {bc}not dark {bc}{sx|pale||}

et: Middle English {it}lyht, light,{/it} going back to Old English {it}lēoht,{/it} Anglian {it}lēht{/it} "filled with light, bright, clear," going back to Germanic {it}*leuhta-{/it} (whence also Old Frisian {it}liācht, licht{/it} "light, bright," Old Saxon {it}lioht,{/it} Middle Dutch {it}licht, lecht,{/it} Old High German {it}lioht, liuhti{/it}), going back to Indo-European {it}*leu̯k-to-,{/it} probably verbal adjective from the base {it}*leu̯k-{/it} "become bright" {ma}{mat|light:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: having light : bright
not intense in color, coloring, or pigmentation : not dark : pale
medium in saturation and high in lightness

et: Middle English {it}lihten, lighten{/it} "to emit light, shine, dawn, shed light on, light (a fire, a candle), set fire to, illuminate," going back to Old English {it}līohtan, līehtan,{/it} Anglian {it}līhtan{/it} "to give light, become light, light (a candle)," going back to Germanic {it}*leuhtije-{/it} (whence also Old Saxon {it}liuhtan{/it} "to shine," Middle Dutch {it}luchten,{/it} Old High German {it}liuhten,{/it} Gothic {it}liuhtjan{/it} "to give light"), weak verb derivative from {it}*leuhta-{/it} "bright, {et_link|light:2|light:2}"
shortdef: to become light : brighten —usually used with up
to take fire
to ignite something (such as a cigarette) —often used with up

{bc}made with a lower calorie content or with less of some ingredient (such as salt, fat, or alcohol) than usual
{bc}producing goods for direct consumption by the consumer
{bc}being in debt to the pot in a poker game

pt: {sc}easy{/sc} {sc}facile{/sc} {sc}simple{/sc} {sc}light{/sc} {sc}effortless{/sc} {sc}smooth{/sc} mean not demanding effort or involving difficulty. {sc}easy{/sc} is applicable either to persons or things imposing tasks or to activity required by such tasks.
{sc}facile{/sc} often adds to {sc}easy{/sc} the connotation of undue haste or shallowness.
{sc}simple{/sc} stresses ease in understanding or dealing with because complication is absent.
{sc}light{/sc} stresses freedom from what is burdensome.
{sc}effortless{/sc} stresses the appearance of ease and usually implies the prior attainment of artistry or expertness.
{sc}smooth{/sc} stresses the absence or removal of all difficulties, hardships, or obstacles.

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}lēoht{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}līhti{/it} light, Latin {it}levis{/it}, Greek {it}elachys{/it} small
shortdef: having little weight : not heavy
designed to carry a comparatively small load
having relatively little weight in proportion to bulk
lightly
with little baggage

dt.t: I {it}lit into{/it} that food until I'd finished off the heel of the loaf

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}līhtan{/it}; akin to Old English {it}lēoht{/it} light in weight
shortdef: dismount
settle, alight
to fall unexpectedly —usually used with on or upon
